body: A train thundered across the Manhattan Bridge, high above the wind-swept streets of Dumbo, where two young graphic designers were trundling a hotel-style luggage cart, loaded with laundry bags and cardboard boxes, toward their building. Jessi Arrington, 28, and Creighton Meshon, 33, were thrilled to hear that their neighborhood had won official
title: DUMBO JOURNAL; As Onetime Newcomers Become Resentful Old-Timers, a Historic District Is Born

body: ALTHOUGH Robyn Sklaren and Brian Fountain's kitchen is spotless, with nice new cabinets and countertops, it has the sad air of neglect. On a recent Sunday morning, no smells of brunch or even boxed doughnuts wafted from the space. ''We're pretty much only good with toast,'' said Ms. Sklaren, 29. It's a fairly big kitchen, flooded with light from a
title: HABITATS; Space To Nurture Obsessions

body: NORA GERAGHTY and Dan Kahn moved into the four-story brick house on Clinton Street in the summer of 2001, a week after graduating from college. By day, their life resembled that of any young couple in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn: coffee from a patisserie on Court Street and commutes on the F train to entry-level jobs in Manhattan. That was by day. By
title: The Ghosts Of Clinton Street

body: To the Editor: Re ''Time to Deal With E-Waste'' (editorial, Dec. 9): You call the City Council's proposal to force manufacturers of electronics to recycle their discarded goods ''progressive.'' It may be progressive, but its workings are a marvelous evasion of the city's responsibility. Expecting New Yorkers to cart old computers or television sets
title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR; Yes, Recycle E-Waste, But With a Public Plan

body: Daniel L. Doctoroff was to have been the Robert Moses of the Bloomberg era, a bold visionary who would guide a sweeping revitalization of New York and put to rest the notion that the age of building big had ended. But now, as Mr. Doctoroff ends his tenure as the longest-serving deputy mayor for economic development, much of his agenda remains
title: Mayor's Big-Thinking Aide Leaves City Hall With Mixed Legacy

title: Spare Times: Nov. 30-Dec. 6

body: WHEN he was 20, Arturo Vidals told his father there were no good job opportunities in his hometown, Puebla, Mexico. ''If you're an eagle, then fly,'' his father replied. Mr. Vidals took a bus to Tijuana and hired a drunken coyote, Mexican slang for a smuggler, to sneak him across the border at San Diego. From there he rode to Los Angeles in the
title: HABITATS; Serendipity Transcends All Barriers

body: If your knowledge of Middle Eastern food starts with falafel and ends with hummus, a few hours on Atlantic Avenue should set you straight. The accuracy half a century later: pretty
title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK | ATLANTIC AVE., BROOKLYN; An Exotic Oasis in Brooklyn

body: THE MOTHER-TO-BE The indie-movie actress Lili Taylor has a new production under way: she is expecting her first baby, a girl, in January. Dressing for her growing girth has required resourcefulness and creativity, said Ms. Taylor, 40, who stars with Frank Langella and Lauren Ambrose in the film ''Starting Out in the Evening,'' in limited release
title: Maternity Jeans

title: Spare Times: For Children

body: A Place to Find That Elusive Book To the Editor: Re ''The Book Angels'' (Oct. 28): I was glad to read about Catherine Bohne and the rescue of her Community Bookstore in Park Slope. That store has rescued me many times when other bookstores wouldn't or couldn't take the time to help me search for a title. Once I needed a book but only knew the
title: THE CITY; Letters to the Editor

title: Spare Times

body: City Councilman Bill de Blasio, who lost a bid last year for Council speaker, said yesterday that he would run for Brooklyn borough president in 2009. Mr. de Blasio, a Democrat, becomes the second candidate to officially enter the race, joining Councilman Charles Barron, who announced his candidacy in May. Marty Markowitz, who has been the borough
title: Councilman Joins Race For Top Seat In Brooklyn

body: REAL ESTATE listings are filled with houses and apartments with sky-high prices. But sometimes, a listing will turn up that seems too good to be true. Usually there's a catch, and the catch is often that the property comes with one or more rent-regulated tenants. While these houses and apartments can sell for hundreds of thousands of dollars less
title: The Price Includes Tenants

body: IT wasn't long ago that Jin Pak declared he would never live north of 14th Street. Shortly after that, his wife, Alexandra Clarke, declared she would never move from Manhattan. When the time came, of course, both assertions fell by the wayside. The couple first lived in Zeckendorf Towers in Union Square, where Ms. Clarke bought a studio condominium
title: THE HUNT; Learning Never to Say Never

title: Spare Times: For Children

title: Calendar

body: IT wasn't supposed to matter to Brooklyn. Heath Ledger, the crown prince of the borough's celebrity aristocracy, apparently fled his fiefdom in Boerum Hill for Manhattan after splitting up with his girlfriend, the actress Michelle Williams. ''To each his own,'' said Jay Wilkinson, 29, an actor who lives in the neighborhood, speaking just blocks
title: Brooklyn's Fragile Ego-System

body: In a country like the United States that loves competition, The Vendy Awards, held yesterday in the East Village to honor the best food to be had at a street cart, do not seem out of the ordinary. But in the Palestinian West Bank, there would be talk. ''We don't have contests like this in the West Bank! I wish!'' exclaimed Fares Zeideia, 41, over
title: City That Eats and Runs Rewards Its Best Vendors

body: FOR CHILDREN JACKSON HEIGHTS KIDS' FILM FESTIVAL It's not easy to find American cinemas that offer samosas (Indian pastries filled with meat or vegetables) along with popcorn and candy. The Eagle Theater in Queens is one, and on Sunday its on-screen fare will be just as eclectic: movies whose flavors range from the richness of Indian immigrant life
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: AFTER years working in the entertainment field, Rosanne Ehrlich knew better than to take rejection personally, even when several co-op boards in Brooklyn Heights turned her down without meeting her. ''It was an enormously valuable life lesson,'' said Ms. Ehrlich, who wanted a studio or one-bedroom costing $300,000 to $375,000. ''I kind of applied
title: THE HUNT; When Smaller Is Better

author: Interviewed by ALEX MINDLIN
body: DAVID HELENE, Cobble Hill, Brooklyn Packer Collegiate Institute BORN July 9, 1990 I LIVE on Clinton Street in Cobble Hill. My dad's a furniture designer and my mom's a literary agent. title: 'Our Year Is the Most Competitive Year in the History of College Applications. Or Something Like That.'

body: FOR CHILDREN THE KITCHEN HIGH LINE BLOCK PARTY It's hard for many New Yorkers to be astonished by anything -- or anyone -- they encounter on the street. title: Spare Times: For Children

body: In its 15-year history American Stevedoring has moved hundreds of thousands of televisions, loaded tons and tons of coffee and shipped and received everything from sofas to ambulances. Now it is hauling its most precious cargo yet: tenors. A 69-year-old former oil tanker moored in the company's container port in Red Hook, Brooklyn, has been
title: Don't Rock the Boat; Opera in Progress

body: Firefighters have very few places they can go to vent, to shed tears or to admit that their job can be overwhelming. One of those places is a small building along the waterfront in Red Hook, Brooklyn, where a group offers counseling and holistic therapy to firefighters and their families. The group, Friends of Firefighters, was established in 2002,
title: Where Firefighters Once Worked, Group Sees a Place to Soothe Their Pain

body: A prisoner who was being treated at a hospital escaped by crashing through a plate-glass window early yesterday morning, the police said. The suspect, Gregory Pollock, 46, was arrested for possession of a controlled substance and resisting arrest. The police said that Mr. Pollock was being treated at Long Island College Hospital in Cobble Hill at
title: METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK; Brooklyn: Prisoner Escapes, Briefly

body: Two years ago Freddy Saint-Aignan and his wife, Angelika, found the perfect location for their fledgling bar/restaurant, the Sugar Lounge: Columbia Street in Brooklyn. The building was just the right size, had a spacious backyard garden and sat beside Upper New York Bay. The city had big plans for the area: green space and parks, cruise ship piers
title: COLUMBIA STREET JOURNAL; Two Years Later, a Street Still Waits For Its Promised Gentrification

body: Elana Karopkin, a Brooklyn native, may have found the last good deal in Cobble Hill when she was just 24.
title: Taking the Plunge

body: VISITING the big city can leave you parched, especially in summer. It's easy to develop a more-than-one-beer thirst as you gamely tramp from museum to museum, from landmark to landmark. But hunting cheap beer on the New York City bar scene is a bit like trying to find a cheetah on the African savanna. Sure, $7 pints dot the landscape like plump
title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK: BARGAIN BARS; For Beer Tastes, on Beer Budgets

body: LAST week on Smith Street, near the Bergen Street subway station in Brooklyn, a team of sharp-looking designers sanded away the last remaining evidence of a ragtag bar called Vegas that once occupied the site. On Thursday, it reopened as the country's 158th Lucky Brand Jeans store, a division of the Liz Claiborne fashion empire. Meanwhile, a block
title: Smith Street Confronts The Corporate Takeover

body: If watching the Tour de France in the comfort of your living room makes you want to hop onto two wheels and race through the streets of Manhattan until you find a decent baguette, then the Tour de France Culinary Bike Tour might be for you. The tour stops at five French restaurants representing different regions of France, like Marseille in
title: COMINGS & GOINGS

body: The peaks of the Lower Manhattan skyline loomed across the East River, and lap swimmers at the end of their lanes briefly gazed at them before their flip turns. ''Just the fact that there's a pool floating out in the river is astounding to me,'' said David K. Bromwich, 28, who biked to the pool at 5:30 a.m. yesterday, two hours before the next
title: After Decades of Dashed Hopes, Brooklyn Swimmers Rejoice in a Pool With a View

body: 333 Henry Street (Pacific Street), Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, (718) 260-8052, hibino-brooklyn.com. It would be easy to walk by Hibino and tag it as just another sushi-and-miso place. title: DINING BRIEFS | NEW PLACES; Dining Briefs

body: ''I used to be someone who wrote new music,'' the composer Judd Greenstein says at the beginning of ''The End of New Music,'' a new video documentary by Stephen S. Taylor. ''But there's a sort of ossified new-music scene that privileges certain things that are no longer relevant to a new generation of composers. There are people for whom it is
title: MUSIC; Rebel Composers on a Rock Tour of Sorts

body: When Philip Nobile reported in 2004 that the assistant principal of the Brooklyn high school where he taught had ordered other teachers to cheat on the scoring of Regents exams, he was embraced by a powerful city investigator as a whistle-blower. His charges led to a full-blown investigation of the Cobble Hill High School of American Studies by the
title: New Report Clears School Of Cheating

body: An article last Thursday about six home kitchens misstated the age for Simone Leigh, an artist whose kitchen is decorated with found objects. She is 39, not 46. The article also misstated the location for Jill's, a restaurant owned by Jill Pettijohn, whose home kitchen was featured. It is in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, not Red Hook.
title: Correction

body: The posting on Craigslist was vague, something about ''set dressing'' and a movie company and a sale. Cash only. But the two words circulating among the Internet cognoscenti, could not have been clearer: ''The Sopranos.'' So it was that nine days after the finale of the HBO mob drama, scores of ''Sopranos'' fans found themselves yesterday in front
title: Seeking a Souvenir of Those Mobsters You Hate to Love

body: THE American kitchen has been an aspirational space ever since electricity and post-World War I prosperity commingled in a nifty new appliance called the refrigerator. ''There are scads of ads from the 1920s showing people in tuxedos and evening gowns literally adoring their fridge,'' said Victoria Matranga, a historian of industrial design and the
title: Kitchen Tales

body: IF you've ever suspected that meatballs were a dead end for a restaurant's leftovers, you no longer have reason to fear. Others are refining more authentic variations that highlight the meatball's global appeal (see also: kofte, nem
title: The Expanding Meatball Universe

body: The city has agreed not to sell a vacant firehouse in Brooklyn, ending a four-year battle between the Bloomberg administration and community activists and local leaders. Engine Company 204 on Degraw Street in Cobble Hill was one of five units closed or relocated during budget cuts in 2003, leaving their firehouses empty. The changes set off
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Rooklyn: Cobble Hill Firehouse Will Not Be Sold

body: The teenager stepped off an airplane at Kennedy International Airport on Nov. 8 and asked for asylum. Days before, he had been wielding an automatic weapon as a child soldier in Ivory Coast. Now he had only his name, Salifou Yankene, and a phrase in halting English: ''I want to make refugee.'' Eventually Salifou's story would emerge, and in
title: Taking the War Out of a Child Soldier

title: Getting Territorial Out in the Hall

author: Andrew Rice, a writer living in Brooklyn, has covered New York real estate. He is now writing a book about Uganda.
body: Mario Procida -- son of a construction boss, grandson of an immigrant stonemason -- was stalking his natural habitat, a building site. As usual, he was doing several things at once, all of them distractedly. The 49-year-old developer had come down from his family firm's office in the Bronx to show me around his latest project, On Prospect Park, a
title: Betting On Star Power

body: WHETHER they preferred apartments uptown or downtown, walk-up or doorman buildings, and old or new construction, many New Yorkers agreed on one thing about the Manhattan real estate market in the last year: it was safer to rent than to buy. Some feared that if they bought, the market would fall. Others simply put off the hassle of buying for as
title: When Renters Reach the Breaking Point

title: SPARE TIMES: Feb. 23 - March 1; For Children

body: Since the new year began, a burst of activity has broken out in Manhattan and several Brooklyn neighborhoods as New Yorkers frenetically hunt for co-ops, condominiums and town houses, sending prices higher despite sluggish sales in many other cities. Preliminary indications from real estate firms showed that this increased activity, with open
title: HOUSING MARKET HEATS UP IN CITY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths HART, KATHERINE P., MBA.

body: THERE are things New York apartments typically lack -- a yard, a parking place, a washer-dryer. But there is one thing they do possess: floor plans, most often derived from buildings' original marketing materials. Floor plans are important when an apartment goes on the market and a listing goes on the Web, real estate agents say, because buyers in
title: Where Floor Plans Are Sought After, and Why

body: Two men died in a Queens apartment building early yesterday when an elevator door gave way as they scuffled and they plunged 11 stories down the shaft, the police said. The deaths came about 24 hours after a man died during a fight in a Chelsea nightclub when he was shoved into a closed elevator door, which opened and allowed him to fall through.
title: Queens Elevator Accident Kills 2, Just After Similar Death at a Club

author: Bonnie Friedman, a professor of creative writing at New York University, is the author of ''Writing Past Dark: Envy, Fear, Distraction and Other Dilemmas in the Writer's Life.''

title: Reality Bites

title: Taking the Middle Schoolers Out of the Middle

body: PEOPLE interested in buying brownstones or town houses should not assume that all of the bargains are gone. title: Finding a Town House for Under a Million
